text: I'm going to be talking about Cupid
today uh which is a backronym so what do
I mean by backronym it's a word that I
made up and then I came up with things
to mean each of the letters so it
started in response to um solid which is
a a proper acronym so solid is the
acronym for five um properties of sorry
five
principles of software development that
Robert Martin articulated in the I guess
in the early 2000s um based on
objectoriented software and then Mike
feathers who was working with him re
noticed that the first five of these
principles if you put them in a
particular order spelled the word
solid so and and they have things like
single responsibility principle and open
close principle and all these things so
in
2017 um for fun I did a lightning talk
about why every element of solid is
wrong and so I went into each of these
into each each of these principles and
said said why I disagree with them and
why they hadn't stood the test of time
and then sometime later someone
challenged me and said okay great well
that's the away from what would you
replace them with and it was in February
it was February a couple years ago so I
thought ah it's the time of year Cupid
you know so I come with Cupid
deliberately as a counter to know solid
is macho and whatever and cupid is
lovely and fluffy so now I had the
problem of coming up with five
properties that that spelled Cupid
and it's great because then you get to
try loads of ideas in your head and so
so the five that one um composability
Unix like so Unix philosophy
predictability uh ID idiomatic and
domain based
okay and so in the talk then I'm going
to unpack what each of those
means and and talk a little bit about
why you know why why the away from is
solid and why the towards is is
Cupid so very briefly composable code is
code that plays well with other code
okay so it's small it has a small
surface area it's easy to understand it
makes sense um it's uh consistently
named that kind of thing so so it means
it's easy to integrate into other
different places so that's composable
Unix like comes back from the Unix
philosophy of doing one thing well so
the Unix command set is lots of tiny
little things like cat just gives you
the contents of a file grep filters that
file said um transforms some text and
and you can chain all these things
together and there's your composability
again but each of these things does one
thing well and that makes it easy to fit
in your head and to make sense
of then p is
predictable uh so this is code that does
what you expect it to do so Kent Beck
famously says right you know I need code
with tests right the first thing code
has to have is test test so I can make
sense of it that's one way of making
code predictable you can I I've I've
written code I've seen code that's so
obvious what it's doing it doesn't need
tests you know like and or code that
you're using all the time so I've I've
written convoluted uh tests for like the
Happy path through a user interface
which someone's using all the time right
if that stops working it's going to be
pretty obvious it isn't working so those
things we don't need necessarily
automated tests what we do need to know
is that every time we use them they do
the same thing again and again and again
so
determinism right and then when you've
got something running in an environment
um then you've got operability
observability is again is all part of
predictability I'm using observability
in the technical sense of I can tell
what something's doing just by observing
its outputs so just by looking at what
it does I can have an opinion about
about what's going on inside and with an
awful lot of code an awful lot of
systems that's not
true so I can look at the the observable
outputs and I've got no idea what's
going going on in there and suddenly it
blows up and I didn't see it coming so
observability is a good is a big deal
and then
idiomatic is write code like everyone
else writes code right idiomatic is the
biggest one is the hardest one for
programmers with big egos to get over
right because I want to write my code in
my way with my Stu no no that's not fair
on other people right write code that
other people would expect to see in
particular you know learn the language
idioms learn the tools chain edms learn
how other people using this stack use
this stack and do it that way and that's
going to be kind of how the language is
written how it libraries work but also
within your team within your
organization how do we write code here
because I'm going to write code here the
same way everyone else writes code here
because then when you come and look at
my code it's not oh no we got Daniel's
code it's we've got some code that I
could have written and there's a whole
layer of cognitive load that just
doesn't
exist and then D domain based and this
is the idea that code should be written
in the language of the domain of of the
problem so if I'm trading and I have
pricing and I have risk then in the code
I want to see references to trading and
pricing and risk not maps of ins of maps
of ins to ins right because because now
again I have to do this internal mapping
in my brain and that's more cognitive
load so the more we can make code
composable Unix like um predictable
idiomatic and domain based the nicer
that code is to work with and the
language I've been using is joyful I've
been talking about code that's joyful to
work
with and the thing that got me on to
this I mean apart from being challenged
to you know what would you replace solid
with is I remember I've been doing this
I've been cutting code for about 30
years it's super I'm in my early 50s
amazing skin I know right but um I've
been doing this for a while and I
remember one of the first code bases I
ever worked on which was back in 1991 I
reckon
um where I went into try and solve there
was a really gnarly bug in there it was
big complicated image processing Digital
Image processing codebase I was the new
kid and I had to go in and try and solve
some you know find some bug in C and if
you've seen code right there's most code
is shocking most C code is why we made
other languages right but it turns out
you can write remarkably good C code and
you can write C code you can write code
in C that is composable Unix like well
Unix is written in C right um that is
UNIX like that is idiomatic and so on
and I remember I cracked open this code
base and I remember as a you know 20s
something bright-eyed fresh graduate
looking at this code and smiling and
going I understand this I can see what's
going on and it was really easy to
navigate and I navigated this code and
and I found where the bug probably was
and it was really obvious it was like a
logic error greater than equals or
something instead of a greater than and
I changed it and I built the code and I
ran it and it all worked I was just like
thank you the person who left this here
right that wasn't me that was the person
who left this here made it super easy
for me to figure that thing out and I
was like I want to pay that forward so
so cupid is my 30-year Arc of attempting
to pay that forward so there you go
that's my
talk
